summary: This is an email chain from September 30, 2019, discussing the processing of electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence. A Senior Forensic Examiner explains delays in creating load files for review due to the volume of data (over 800,000 emails from one machine) and prioritization of materials from Epstein's island. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York inquires about the number of processed devices.

persons.name: Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Responds to an inquiry about processing electronic evidence from Epstein's New York residence, explaining technical delays and prioritization of materials from the island.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.role: Federal prosecutor in the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Inquires about the number of electronic devices seized from Epstein's New York house that were processed by CART, noting received materials seem fewer than expected.

connections.description: The forensic examiner is communicating with the prosecutor about the status of evidence processing in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Email discussion on evidence processing
events.description: Email correspondence regarding the processing of electronic evidence seized from Epstein's New York residence, revealing technical challenges and volume of data.

locations: New York house (Epstein's New York residence)
the Island (likely referring to Epstein's private island, Little St. James)
keyFacts: One machine from Epstein's New York residence contained over 800,000 emails, indicating massive volume of electronic evidence.
Processing was delayed because load files could only be generated with 25,000 entries at a time, creating technical bottlenecks.
Materials from Epstein's island had an expiration date and took priority in processing over New York residence materials.
Approximately 38 computers/electronic storage devices and approximately 55 CDs were seized from the New York residence according to an attached list referenced in the email.
